channel.title: WSJ.com: Economy
channel.copyright: Copyright © Dow Jones & Company, Inc. All rights reserved.

item.title: Nineteen states raised their minimum wage starting this month, providing a pay bump to an estimated 8.3 million workers
item.description: A mix of 19 states, both red and blue, bumped their minimum wages this month, several to over $15 an hour.
item.dc:creator: Jared Mitovich

item.title: U.K. Shop Price Inflation Rose in December on Higher Food Prices
item.description: U.K. shop and food price inflation ticked higher in December, when shoppers leaned into promotions to alleviate cost pressures, according to an industry report.
item.dc:creator: Aimee Look

item.title: French Inflation Fell Slightly in December
item.description: French inflation fell slightly in December, reinforcing the European Central Bank’s view that the eurozone remained in a “good place” after keeping rates on hold.
item.dc:creator: Don Nico Forbes

item.title: Democrats’ appetite for another shutdown looks diminished in the wake of the 43-day government-funding lapse, driven by centrists who worry that too much damage was inflicted on American households
item.description: Centrists worry that too much damage was inflicted on U.S. households during the 43-day government-funding lapse, hurting voters they are trying to help.
item.dc:creator: Siobhan Hughes

item.title: Two new studies offer a surprising answer to the question of whether tariffs cause inflation
item.description: A blow to consumer and business demand likely explains why tariffs’ impact on inflation is limited.
item.dc:creator: Konrad Putzier

item.title: Capital Account: The U.S. had countless reasons for wanting regime change in Venezuela. Yet one factor appears to have been decisive for President Trump: oil.
item.description: Under the president’s version of the Monroe Doctrine, commerce and resources drive U.S. strategic intervention. Is Greenland next?
item.dc:creator: Greg Ip

item.title: Heard on the Street: Tax cuts will help pad wallets in 2026, but not across all income levels
item.description: The tax cuts should help some people, but changes to programs such as food stamps will hurt low-income consumers.
item.dc:creator: Jinjoo Lee

item.title: For five older job seekers, finding new work took creativity, new skills and, in some cases, lowered expectations
item.description: Finding new work took creativity, new skills and, in some cases, lowered expectations.
item.dc:creator: Lindsay Ellis

item.title: Why pay more? This couple left pricey California behind for a spacious, affordable home in the Midwest
item.description: The region offers housing costs below the national median and steady wage growth.
item.dc:creator: Paul Overberg

item.title: “We’re going to lose big time.” Why condo owners are struggling with the worst market in more than 10 years.
item.description: Condo prices this fall posted their biggest declines since 2012, hit by rising homeowner-association dues and weaker demand.
item.dc:creator: Nicole Friedman

item.title: President Trump delayed by a year tariff increases on upholstered furniture, kitchen cabinets and vanities, the latest move to walk back levies in the face of consumer frustration over prices
item.description: It is the latest move by the president to walk back levies in the face of consumer frustration over the cost of living.
item.dc:creator: Alex Frangos

item.title: South Korea’s exports posted stronger-than-expected growth on brisk semiconductor demand in the year’s final month and set an annual record in 2025
item.description: The country’s exports posted stronger-than-expected growth on brisk semiconductor demand in the year’s final month and set an annual record in 2025.
item.dc:creator: Kwanwoo Jun

item.title: The number of Americans who filed for new unemployment benefits decreased in the Christmas holiday week
item.description: New claims fell in the holiday week but stayed near a monthslong range, as U.S. employers hesitate to let go of their workforce.
item.dc:creator: Paulo Trevisani

item.title: Instead of crumbling under the highest U.S. tariffs in almost a century, the global trade system has been recast along new lines. Here are six stories of how.
item.description: Six stories that show how real people and companies in the global economy are rapidly adjusting to the new rules of trade.
item.dc:creator: Shan Li

item.title: Chicago Fed Estimates Flat December Unemployment Rate
item.description: An estimate by the Chicago Fed forecasts that unemployment held steady in December at 4.6%, the reserve bank said.
item.dc:creator: Matt Grossman

item.title: Some Federal Reserve officials said they were hesitant to support further interest-rate cuts soon, according to minutes released Tuesday, signaling potential resistance to another cut at the January meeting
item.description: At the December meeting, some officials backed holding rates steady “for some time.”
item.dc:creator: Matt Grossman

item.title: U.S. Home Prices Keep Slow Growth Pace
item.description: S&P Cotality Case-Shiller National Home Price Index rose 1.4% in 12 months through October, compared with a 1.3% rise in September. This represents weakest performance since mid-2023.
item.dc:creator: Paulo Trevisani

item.title: Investors are bracing for a central bank marked by unusual division, a potentially weaker chair and the threat of more radical change
item.description: Markets have been calm but concerns persist about a less independent, more divided central bank.
item.dc:creator: Sam Goldfarb

item.title: Bank of Japan’s Meeting Summary Points to Further Rate Increases
item.description: A member of the Japanese central bank’s policy board said that raising the policy interest rate in a timely manner could curb future inflationary pressure.
item.dc:creator: Kosaku Narioka

item.title: The corporate playbook for next year? Don’t hire.
item.description: Large employers indicate that they either want to maintain the size of their teams next year or let go of workers.
item.dc:creator: Chip Cutter

item.title: Mexico braced for a tariff hit when Trump raised trade barriers. Instead, its exports to the U.S. surged—helped by lower rates than rivals.
item.description: Its exports to the U.S. have surged since President Trump imposed new import duties on countries this year.
item.dc:creator: Anthony Harrup

item.title: Tens of thousands of imports are being stopped from entering the U.S. Those that can’t clear customs because of missing or incomplete information are returned—or destroyed.
item.description: Small imports that had cleared U.S. customs quickly and easily are now stranded because of changing tariffs and tougher enforcement.
item.dc:creator: Esther Fung

item.title: Japan Closer to Achieving 2% Inflation Target, BOJ Governor Says
item.description: Bank of Japan Gov. Kazuo Ueda said Thursday that the central bank is getting closer to achieving its 2% inflation target, reaffirming his stance of seeking further interest-rate increases.

item.title: Jobless Claims Fell Last Week
item.description: The number of Americans who filed for new unemployment benefits declined last week, as the U.S. labor market faces heightened economic uncertainty.
item.dc:creator: Paulo Trevisani

item.title: Capital Account: President Trump’s social-media post shows worries about Kevin Hassett miss the point. Trump’s conditions compromise all the candidates.
item.description: President Trump’s social-media post shows worries about Kevin Hassett miss the point. Trump’s conditions compromise all the candidates.
item.dc:creator: Greg Ip

item.title: The U.S. economy continues to power through the trade and immigration shocks of 2025, defying widespread expectations of a slowdown or even a recession
item.description: The unrelenting American consumer spends through a sour mood and a cooling labor market.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Wolfe

item.title: Canada’s Consumer Heads Into 2026 on Firmer Footing
item.description: Canada’s consumer is exiting 2025 in better shape compared with earlier in the year after shrugging off concerns of a trade war and other macroeconomic concerns that had weighed on spending.
item.dc:creator: Adriano Marchese

item.title: China Vanke’s Brewing Crisis Suggests Limited Property Easing to Come
item.description: Many of China’s other large developers have already defaulted, and a Vanke collapse would raise questions about how policymakers plan to address the real-estate slump as it drags on into a sixth year in 2026.

item.title: Millions of homeowners are still locked into ultralow mortgage rates they don’t want to give up
item.description: Nearly 30 million households, or 54% of primary mortgage-holders, have mortgage rates at or below 4%.
item.dc:creator: Nicole Friedman

item.title: Consumer Sentiment Rose in December but Remains Dim, Michigan Survey Suggests
item.description: Consumers’ economic mood recovered slightly in December but remained broadly gloomy as households face drawn-out inflation and a frustrating labor market for job seekers.
item.dc:creator: Matt Grossman

item.title: Consumer prices rose 2.7% in November from a year earlier, slowing from 3% in September
item.description: Consumer prices rose 2.7% in November from a year earlier, according to a delayed government report, slowing from 3% in September.
item.dc:creator: Matt Grossman

item.title: Eurozone Economy Posts Stronger Growth on Investment Rebound
item.description: The economy grew at a faster pace than estimated in the three months through September, aided by a pickup in investment.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: Growth to Slow as Tariffs Bite, but AI Investments May Cushion the Blow
item.description: The OECD forecast the global economy to expand by 2.9% next year, a slowdown from 3.2% this year.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: China Private Gauge Signals Weaker Manufacturing Activity
item.description: Growth in China’s manufacturing production came to a halt as new orders nearly stalled last month despite a renewed rise in new orders from abroad.

item.title: Parts of Europe at Risk of Downward ‘Spiral’ if Older Voters Stymie Reforms, EBRD Warns
item.description: Economies that escaped from Communism are at risk if older voters and political leaders prevent changes to offset aging populations.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: Threats to Eurozone Financial Stability ‘Remain Elevated,’ Says ECB’s De Guindos
item.description: A large-scale trade war has been averted, but uncertainty remains high about government policies that can affect the financial system, the European Central Bank vice president said.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon
